THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Theodore David
      Wills, Jr., Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4742
Submitted September 1, 2010 â€“ Filed
  September 22, 2010Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Senior Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for
  Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all
  of Columbia; and Solicitor J. Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Â Theodore David Wills, Jr. appeals his murder
  conviction and forty-year sentence, arguing the trial court erred in admitting
  his statement in violation of Rule 410, SCRE.Â  We affirm. [1]
FACTS
Wills
  was charged with murdering Julian Lee.Â  Prior to his trial, Wills entered into
  a proffer agreement with the State, reviewed and signed by his attorney,
  whereby he agreed to truthfully divulge the events and circumstances
  surrounding Lee's death in exchange for the State's consideration and a
  recommended sentence.Â  The agreement contained several conditions, including
  Wills's submission to a polygraph examination to test the veracity of his
  statement. Â Additionally, the agreement provided:

	[U]pon
  examination(s) by polygraph, if the responses given by Theodore David Wills Jr.
  show deception, are inconsistent with information previously provided or
  indicates he is the person or one of the persons that shot the victim, the
  terms of this proffer are null and void and any statements made by Theodore
  David Wills Jr. may be used against him by the State for any legal purpose,
  including, but not limited to, considerations for charging, bond, disposition
  of charges through plea or trial of Theodore David Wills Jr. and impeachment.

After Wills gave a
  video-taped proffer statement, the polygraph was administered and the State
  determined Wills was untruthful.Â  
At
  trial, Wills opposed the statement's introduction, and after a Jackson v.
    Denno, 378 U.S. 368 (1964), hearing, the trial court found the statement
  was voluntary and admissible on the conditions both parties would refrain from
  mentioning the polygraph, and the videotape would be redacted where Wills
  referenced his previous incarceration and the polygraph.Â  Wills was convicted
  as charged and sentenced to forty years' imprisonment.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  admission of evidence is within the discretion of the trial court and will not
  be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Pagan,
  369 S.C. 201, 208, 631 S.E.2d 262, 265 (2006).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs
  when the trial court's conclusions either lack evidentiary support or are
  controlled by an error of law.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
"Rule
  410[, SCRE,] provides . . . a statement made during plea negotiations with a
  prosecuting authority, even if a guilty plea is not entered or is later
  withdrawn, is not admissible."Â  State v. Compton, 366 S.C. 671,
  679, 623 S.E.2d 661, 665 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
In Compton,
  this court addressed the admissibility of a defendant's statements procured
  pursuant to an agreement with the State.Â  Id.Â  Otis James Compton was
  questioned about an unsolved murder prior to pleading guilty to unrelated
  counts of burglary.Â  Id. at 675, 623 S.E.2d at 663.Â  At all times,
  Compton remained a person of interest in the murder investigation.Â  Id.Â 
  While incarcerated, Compton pled to additional charges unrelated to the murder
  and was placed in a holding cell.Â  Id.Â  Compton initiated a conversation
  with his holding cellmate regarding the unsolved murder, admitting his involvement.Â  Id.Â  Approximately two months later, the cellmate was transferred to
  Compton's prison and asked by investigators to listen to Compton about the
  unsolved murder.Â  Id. at 675-76, 623 S.E.2d at 663.Â  The cellmate
  acquiesced and reported several conversations to investigators.Â  Id. at
  676, 623 S.E.2d at 663.
Eight
  months after his initial plea, Compton contacted investigators regarding the
  unsolved murder and entered into a written agreement labeled "Plea
  Agreement" whereby Compton agreed to fully and truthfully cooperate in the
  murder investigation.Â  Id. at 676, 623 S.E.2d at 663-64.Â  In exchange
  for his cooperation, the State agreed to reduce all sentences Compton was
  serving for the unrelated burglary charges.Â  Id. at 676, 623 S.E.2d at
  664.Â  As a result of his cooperation during the investigation, Compton was
  indicted for murder.Â  Id.Â  Pretrial, Compton moved to suppress his
  statements, arguing they were subject to an immunity agreement and precluded by
  Rule 410, SCRE.Â  Id.Â  The trial court admitted the statements after
  finding no reasonable expectation of immunity existed and the statements were
  not procured during plea negotiations.Â  Id.Â  
On
  appeal, this court examined the "Plea Agreement," and determined the
  agreement did not contain an immunity clause.Â  Id. at 676-78, 623 S.E.2d
  664-65.Â  In construing the agreement, our court stated "immunity
  agreements and plea agreements are to be construed in accordance with general
  contract principles."Â  Id. at 677, 623 S.E.2d at 664.Â  Thus,
  "[t]he court must enforce an unambiguous contract according to its terms,
  regardless of the contract's wisdom or folly, or the parties' failure to guard
  their rights carefully."Â  Id. at 678, 623 S.E.2d at 665.Â  Likewise,
  this court determined the admission of Compton's statements did not offend Rule
  410, SCRE.Â  Id. at 679, 623 S.E.2d at 665.Â  This court held Rule 410,
  SCRE, did not preclude the admission because the statements were not procured
  in the course of plea negotiations when the negotiation "related to the
  reduction in sentence for the burglary" convictions.Â  Id.Â  Specifically,
  our court stated the discussions "were not in furtherance of Compton
  making a plea on any charges."Â  Id.
Applying
  the principles of Compton to the instant facts, an ambiguity in South
  Carolina law seems to emerge.Â  Our case law unequivocally establishes
  agreements between defendants and the State should be interpreted "in
  accordance with general contract principles."Â  Id. at 677, 623
  S.E.2d at 664.Â  However, by examining the admissibility of Compton's statements[2] under Rule 410, SCRE, our court has left the precise question of whether an
  agreement can waive the application of the Rules of Evidence unanswered.Â  
While
  no South Carolina case law specifically discusses whether a defendant can waive
  the exclusionary provisions of Rule 410, SCRE, the United States Supreme Court
  addressed waiver of the exclusionary provisions of Rule 410, FRE, in United
    States v. Mezzanatto, 513 U.S. 196, 200 (1995).[3]Â 
  Gary Mezzanatto was arrested and charged with possession with intent to
  distribute methamphetamine after attempting to sell an undercover officer drugs.Â  Id. at 198.Â  The controlled buy was arranged by an informant who was
  arrested a few hours before Mezzanatto for operating a methamphetamine
  laboratory in his residence.Â  Id. at 197-98.Â  Pretrial, Mezzanatto and
  his attorney contacted the prosecutor to discuss the possibility of cooperating
  with the government.Â  Id. at 198.Â  The prosecutor informed Mezzanatto he
  was under no obligation to talk; however, the prosecutor stated Mezzanatto
  would have to be completely truthful if he wanted to cooperate with the
  government.Â  Id.Â  Additionally, Mezzantto orally agreed, with advice of
  his counsel, "that any statements he made during the meeting could be used
  to impeach any contradictory testimony he might give at trial if the case
  proceeded that far."Â  Id.Â  
During
  the meeting, Mezzanatto attempted to minimize his involvement in distributing
  methamphetamine and claimed he had not visited the methamphetamine laboratory
  at the informant's residence for at least a week before his arrest.Â  Id. at 199.Â  After showing Mezzanatto video surveillance of his vehicle at the
  methamphetamine laboratory the day before his arrest, the government terminated
  the meeting due to Mezzanatto's deceit.Â  Id.Â  
Accordingly,
  Mezzanatto was tried, and during his cross-examination, the prosecutor
  impeached him using the statements procured during the cooperation meeting.Â  Id.Â 
  Mezzanatto was ultimately convicted.Â  Id.Â  On appeal to the Ninth
  Circuit Court of Appeals, Mezzanatto's conviction was reversed.Â  Id.Â 
  The Ninth Circuit "held [Mezzanatto's] agreement to allow admission of his
  plea statements for purposes of impeachment was unenforceable."Â  Id.Â 
  The United States Supreme Court granted certiorari and reversed the Ninth
  Circuit, stating:Â  "The presumption of waivability has found specific
  application in the context of evidentiary rules.Â  Absent some 'overriding
  procedural consideration that prevents enforcement of the contract,' courts
  have held that agreements to waive evidentiary rules are generally enforceable
  even over a party's subsequent objections."Â  Id. at 202 (citation
  omitted).Â  Furthermore, the Court held "absent some affirmative indication
  that the agreement was entered into unknowingly or involuntarily, an agreement
  to waive the exclusionary provisions of the plea-statement Rules is valid and
  enforceable." Â Id. at 210.
Here,
  the principles of Mezzanatto are instructive in determining whether
  Wills's statements were properly admitted.Â  First, we note the proffer
  agreement between Wills and the State constituted a plea negotiation and
  triggered the exclusionary provisions of Rule 410, SCRE.Â  Likewise, any
  statements procured in execution of the agreement were unequivocally in
  furtherance of Wills entering a plea on his pending charges.Â  Second,
  construing the proffer agreement in accordance with general contract
  principles, regardless of the agreement's wisdom or lack thereof, the agreement
  unambiguously provides Wills's statement can be used against him by the State for any legal purpose if the State determines Wills was
  deceitful.Â  Thus, we hold the proffer agreement waived the protections of Rule
  410, SCRE.Â  Next, we must determine whether an affirmative indication that
  Wills entered the agreement unknowingly or involuntarily exists.Â  Because Wills
  entered the proffer agreement with advice of counsel, evidenced by counsel's co-signature,
  and the record lacks support for a finding to the contrary, we find the
  agreement was knowingly and voluntarily entered.Â  Therefore, the trial court
  properly admitted Wills's statements as evidence against him at trial.Â  
Accordingly, Wills's conviction is
AFFIRMED.
WILLIAMS,
  PIEPER, and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.Â  


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Compton was also subjected to a polygraph, and the
  State determined he was deceitful.Â  Compton, 336 S.C. at 676, 623 S.E.2d
  at 664.Â  However, in his appeal, we declined to address whether Compton's
  breach of the agreement contributed to his statements' admissibility because
  the issue was not properly before this court.Â  Id. at 679 n.2, 623
  S.E.2d at 665 n.2.
[3] Rule 410, SCRE, is substantially similar to Rule 410,
  FRE.Â  Compare Rule 410, FRE, and Mezzanatto, 513 U.S. at
  197 ("Federal Rule of Evidence 410 and Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure
  11(e)(6) provide that statements made in the course of plea discussions between
  a criminal defendant and a prosecutor are inadmissible against the
  defendant."), with Rule 410, SCRE, and Compton, 366
  S.C. at 679, 623 S.E.2d at 665 ("Rule 410 provides that evidence of a
  guilty plea that is later withdrawn or evidence of a plea of nolo contendere is
  inadmissible against a defendant.Â  Furthermore, statements made in the course
  of court proceedings related to such pleas are not admissible.Â  Likewise, a
  statement made during plea negotiations with a prosecuting authority, even if a
  guilty plea is not entered or is later withdrawn, is not admissible.").

title: State v. Garrard
description: The Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services appeals the trial judge's decision not to revoke Ronald Garrard's participation in the Community Supervision Program.  In its opinion affirming the trial judge, the court of appeals defines "willfulness" under the program, and discusses the scope of a trial judge's discretion, both in terms of her decision not to revoke,  and in deciding whether to hold a hearing under the Victim's Rights Act.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Appellant,
        v.
        Ronald Garrard, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â  Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4743
  Submitted May 3, 2010 â€“ Filed September
22, 2010

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        John Benjamin Aplin, of Columbia, for
          Appellant.
        Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for
          Respondent.
      
    
  

FEW, C.J.: Ronald
  Garrard served a six-year prison sentence for criminal sexual conduct with a
  minor in the first degree. Â He was released from prison on March 1,
  2006, and entered the community supervision program as required by section
  24-21-560(A) of the South Carolina Code (2007). Â He committed no violations of
  the program's terms during 2006 and 2007.Â  On December 31, 2007, he helped his
  brother move a washer and dryer for their mother.Â  In the course of doing this,
  Garrard briefly stopped at his brother's workplace, approximately 750 feet from
  Lexington High School.Â  The State[1] charged him with violating number five of the sex offender conditions for
  community supervision which states: "I will not enter into, loiter or work
  within one thousand . . . feet of any area or event frequented by people under
  the age of 18 including but not limited to: schools . . . ."Â  Garrard
  conceded he entered within one thousand feet of the school, and thus that he
  violated the terms of condition five.Â  He denied the violation was willful.Â  The
  trial judge initially ruled Garrard had committed a willful violation.Â  After
  a motion to reconsider, however, she reversed her decision and ruled that the
  violation was not willful.
The
  State contends the trial judge abused her discretion in finding that Garrard
  did not commit a willful violation. Â The State also contends the court violated
  the Victim's Rights Act by not holding a hearing on Garrard's motion to reconsider.Â 
  We affirm.
I. Community
  Supervision Program
A. Definition of "Willfully"
The
  community supervision program is operated by the South Carolina Department of
  Probation, Parole and Pardon Services. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-560(A) & (B)
  (2007).Â  When the department determines that a participant has committed a
  violation warranting revocation, "a probation agent must initiate a
  proceeding in General Sessions Court."Â  Id. Â§ 560(C).Â  A circuit
  judge then "shall determine whether . . . Â the prisoner has willfully
  violated a term of the community supervision program."Â  Id. Â§ 560(C)(5).Â 
  In this appeal, we must determine what the Legislature meant in using the term "willfully."Â 
  The State contends that simply because Garrard was physically located less than
  one thousand feet from the school, he committed a willful violation.Â  We
  disagree.
Our
  appellate courts have defined "willful" in a variety of contexts.Â  In
  each instance, the court has required a showing of a consciousness of
  wrongdoing in order to prove willfulness.Â  See, e.g., S.C. Dep't of Soc. Servs. v. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 53, 413 S.E.2d 835, 839 (1992) (In the context of
  termination of parental rights, "[c]onduct
  of the parent which evinces a settled purpose to forego parental duties may
  fairly be characterized as 'willful' because it manifests a conscious
  indifference to the rights of the child."); Kuznik v. Bees Ferry Assocs., 342
  S.C. 579, 611, 538 S.E.2d 15, 32 (Ct. App. 2000) (In the context of punitive
  damages, "[w]illfulness has been defined as a conscious failure to exercise due care.").
  Â In the context of contempt, our supreme court defined a willful act "as
  one 'done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do
  something the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something
  the law requires to be done . . . .'" Â State v.
    Sowell, 370 S.C. 330, 336, 635 S.E.2d 81, 83 (2006) (quoting Spartanburg
      County Dep't of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872,
  874 (1988)).Â  In both Sowell and Padgett, the supreme court
  quoted Black's Law Dictionary in defining "willful."Â  See id. Â Black's Law Dictionary defines "willful" as "[p]roceeding
  from a conscious motion of the will; voluntary.Â  Intending the result which
  actually comes to pass; designed; intentional; not accidental or involuntary."Â  Black's Law Dictionary 1434 (5th ed. 1979).[2]
These
  general definitions are appropriate to use in construing the term "willfully"
  in section 24-21-560(C)(5).Â  We find support for this conclusion in this court's
  opinion in State v. Spare, 374 S.C. 264, 647 S.E.2d 706 (Ct. App. 2007).Â 
  In the closely related context of an alleged violation of probation, the Spare court explained the requirements for proving "willfulness" to
  establish a violation for failure to pay money.[3]Â 
  374 S.C. at 269-70, 647 S.E.2d at 708-09.Â  The court began by stating: "'Willful failure to pay means a voluntary, conscious and
  intentional failure.'"Â  374 S.C. at 269, 647 S.E.2d at 708 (quoting People v. Davis, 576 N.E.2d 510, 513 (Ill. App. Ct. 1991)).Â  The
  court then referenced Sowell, and quoted the passage from Sowell cited earlier in this opinion.Â  374 S.C. at 269, 647 S.E.2d at 708.Â  Following
  these general definitions, we construe the term "willfully" as used
  in this section to require that the State prove either: (1) a voluntary and
  intentional act done with consciousness that the act is a violation of a term
  of the community supervision program, or (2) the voluntary and intentional
  failure to do something known to be required by a term of community
  supervision.
In
  his motion to reconsider, Garrard cited Spare in arguing that the judge
  had applied the incorrect definition for "willful."Â  The trial judge
  relied on Spare in changing her ruling to conclude that the State had
  failed to prove a willful violation.Â  We hold the trial judge used the correct
  definition of "willfully" after reconsideration.Â  Depending on the
  facts of a particular case and the nature of an alleged violation, the specific
  facts the State must prove may vary.Â  In order to prove a willful violation in
  this case, the State was required to prove that Garrard voluntarily and
  intentionally went within one thousand feet of a school, and that he knew doing
  so was a violation of a term of the community supervision program.[4]
B. Trial Judge's
  Discretion
Both
  the decision of whether an alleged violation was willful and the decision of
  whether to revoke community supervision are discretionary.Â  The trial court will
  not be reversed unless the appellant has shown an abuse of that discretion.Â  See State v. Allen, 370 S.C. 88, 94, 634 S.E.2d 653, 655 (2006) (applying an abuse of
  discretion standard of review to the related context of an appeal from an order
  revoking probation).Â  Where there is any evidence to support the court's factual findings,
  there is no abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â  We find evidence to support the trial
  court's factual determination that the violation was not willful. Â First, Garrard
  described the incident as follows: "I pulled into this business and got
  out of my truck and got in his truck and I drove and got a washer and dryer and
  came back to his business and got in my truck and drove off. . . . I was not
  there a total of four minutes there and back."Â  Second, in response to the
  judge's questions, Garrard testified that his violation was not willful. Â He
  also testified he did not know that working at his brother's workplace was
  impermissible. Â This testimony was supported by Garrard's treating therapist
  for the previous two years, Dr. Lazarus, who suggested that Garrard had worked
  hard to remain in compliance with the terms of community supervision.Â  Dr.
  Lazarus testified that Garrard had "been exemplary in following exactly my
  directions, my recommendations," and that Garrard "is at the lowest
  level that is possible for reoffending." Â 
Finally,
  the trial judge repeatedly asked the probation officer representing the State
  at the hearing to address whether the violation was willful.Â  The officer never
  gave a direct answer, stating at one point "we are going to leave that to
  the judge's discretion."Â  The trial judge finally asked "you are
  telling me you don't feel it was willful? . . . I need you to be honest with
  me."Â  The officer replied merely that she felt a verbal reprimand was
  sufficient to address Garrard's violation. Â The trial judge's finding that the
  State had not proven a willful violation was within her discretion.
II. Victim's
  Rights Act
In
  its return to Garrard's motion to reconsider, the State requested that the
  trial judge hold a hearing.Â  The State now contends the decision not to conduct
  a hearing violated the Victim's Rights Act.Â  We disagree.Â  The Act requires the
  State to "attempt to notify each victim, who has indicated a desire to be
  notified, of post-conviction proceedings affecting the . . . release of the
  offender, . . . and of the victim's right to attend and comment at these proceedings."Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-1560(A) (2003).Â  When an offender files a motion to
  reconsider a decision to revoke community supervision, the section requires the
  State to notify the victim that the motion has been filed.Â  See id.Â 
  If the trial judge chooses to hold a hearing on the motion, then the section
  requires the State to notify the victim of her right to "attend and
  comment."Â  See id.Â  The section says nothing, however, about
  whether the judge must choose to hold a hearing.Â  In fact, while the judge
  should give a reasonable opportunity to allow the State to comply with section 16-3-1560(A),[5] the section imposes no requirement whatsoever on the judge.
We
  hold the decision of whether to conduct a hearing on a motion to reconsider the
  revocation of community supervision is within the discretion of the trial
  court.Â  See Rule 29, SCRCrimP (A post-trial "motion may, in the
  discretion of the court, be determined on briefs filed by the parties without
  oral argument.").Â  If there is any reasonable basis for the decision not
  to hold a hearing, the decision will be affirmed on appeal.Â  In this case, no
  additional evidence was offered in the motion to reconsider or in the State's
  return.Â  Rather, the motion focused on the proper definition of "willfulness,"
  and whether the evidence already offered was sufficient for the State to meet
  its burden to prove the violation was willful.Â  Under these circumstances, the
  trial judge's decision not to hold a hearing was within her discretion. 
AFFIRMED.
PIEPER,
  J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1] The State is
  represented by the South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon
  Services at hearings on alleged violations of community supervision.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-560(A) & (C) (2007).
[2] Sowell and Padgett quote the fifth edition.Â  The definition of
  "willful" in the current edition is shorter, but essentially the
  same: "[v]oluntary and intentional, but not necessarily malicious."Â  Black's
    Law Dictionary 1737 (9th ed. 2009).Â  "Willfulness" is defined in
  the ninth edition as "[t]he voluntary, intentional violation or disregard of
  a known legal duty." Id.
[3] Willfulness is
  not normally required in order to prove a violation of probation.Â  For alleged
  violations based solely on a failure to pay money, however, as was the case in Spare,
  the State must prove willfulness before a circuit judge may revoke probation. See State v. Hamilton, 333 S.C. 642, 649, 511
  S.E.2d 94, 97 (Ct. App. 1999).
[4] In its brief,
  the State argues the trial judge "confuses the intent behind the actual
  violation charged (to knowingly enter an area within one thousand feet of a
  school) with the intent to commit a bad act once he entered the area."Â  We
  do not believe the trial judge was confused at all. Rather, she used the
  correct definition of willfully in finding "[t]he evidence presented
  demonstrated a lack of willfulness to violate the terms of his
  supervision."Â  In the context of the violation of community
  supervision alleged in this case, the definition of willfulness does not
  require that the State prove Garrard intended to disobey or disregard the law
  while within one thousand feet of the school.Â  Rather, proof that he intended
  to go to the location, and that he knew doing so was a violation, would have
  been sufficient to prove willfulness.
[5] No section of
  the Act specifically addresses a circuit judge's responsibilities regarding a
  motion or proceeding after conviction.Â  However, two sections address a circuit
  judge's responsibilities in hearings and proceedings conducted before
  conviction.Â  See S.C. Code Â§Â§ 16-3-1525 & 1550 (2003).Â  In both of
  those sections, the circuit judge is generally required to verify the State's
  compliance with the Act, and to allow reasonable time for the State to comply
  if it has previously failed to do so.

L. appeals the termination of her parental rights to her minor child pursuant to sections 20-7-1572 (3) and (4) of the South Carolina Code (2007) (current version at 63-7-2570(3) & (4) (2010)) (willful failure to visit and willful failure to support, respectively).  We reverse and remand to the family court for a permanency planning hearing.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        South Carolina
          Department of Social Services, Respondent,
        v.
        M. R. C. L., R.
          L., and G. L., Defendants,
        Of whom M. R. C.
          L. is Appellant,
        In the Interest
          of One Minor Child.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
W. Thomas Sprott, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4744
  Submitted September 1, 2010 â€“ Filed
September 22, 2010Â Â Â  

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Phillip S. Ferderigos and Jeremy E. Bowers, both of Charleston,
          for Appellant.
        Paul C. White, of Moncks Corner, for Respondent.
        Tammie Lynn Hoffman, of North Charleston, for Guardian ad Litem.Â  
      
    
  

KONDUROS, J.: M. R. C. L. (Mother) appeals the
  termination of her parental rights to her minor child (Child) pursuant to
  sections 20-7-1572 (3) and (4) of the South Carolina Code (2007) (current
  version at 63-7-2570(3) & (4) (2010)) (willful failure to visit and willful
  failure to support, respectively).Â  We reverse and remand to the family court
  for a permanency planning hearing.[1]Â  
FACTS
On
  May 25, 2007, after Mother and R. L. (Father) tested positive for cocaine,
  Child was removed from their home.[2]Â 
  Child was one year old at the time of removal.Â  Child was placed in a
  pre-adoptive foster home with two of her sisters.Â  
Following
  a merits hearing on October 22, 2007, the family court ordered Mother and
  Father to complete a treatment plan including mental health assessments, parent
  evaluations, alcohol and drug assessments, and other recommendations.Â  In
  addition, the family court ordered them to provide Child with safe and
  appropriate housing,[3] report their legal income, pay child support, and complete "an extensive
  parenting course."Â  Mother and Father failed to complete the alcohol and
  drug assessments, parenting classes, and home safety improvements necessary for
  DSS to return Child to them.[4]Â 
  Although Father paid some child support from his Social Security disability
  benefits, Mother, a homemaker, paid nothing.Â  
In
  April 2008, DSS initiated termination of parental rights (TPR) proceedings.Â 
  The complaint for TPR alleged as statutory grounds meriting TPR (1) willful
  failure to visit, (2) willful failure to support, (3) failure to remedy the
  condition leading to removal, (4) a diagnosable condition that was unlikely to
  change and that prevented Mother from providing Child with "minimally
  acceptable care," and (5) harm or neglect of Child from which the home
  cannot likely be made safe within twelve months.Â  Moreover, the complaint
  indicated Child had remained in foster care continuously since her removal from
  Mother.Â  Both parents testified at the November 3, 2008 TPR hearing.Â  Mother stated
  they lived in a two-bedroom trailer home.Â  According to Father, their income
  consisted of his Social Security disability benefits of approximately $689 per
  month and occasional income he earned by doing odd jobs and lawn care.Â  In
  addition to everyday expenses, Father had recently purchased new cell phones
  for himself and Mother at a cost of $100 each.Â  Their monthly expenses included
  approximately $50 per month for food and healthcare for their ten dogs and $30
  per month for cellular telephone service.[5]Â 
  An unspecified amount of Father's Social Security disability benefits went to
  support Child.Â  
When
  Mother last worked in April 2004, she held three jobs.Â  Mother suffered from
  diabetes during her pregnancy with Child.Â  A degenerative disk disease
  prevented her from doing jobs that included lifting heavy objects.Â  At the time
  of the TPR hearing, Mother had applied unsuccessfully for approximately thirty
  jobs.Â  She was on probation for assault on a child, and she admitted driving
  while her driver's license was suspended.Â  However, Mother denied doing drugs,
  including smoking crack cocaine.Â  
Mother
  testified she visited Child in foster care fourteen times.Â  However, a court
  order prevented her from visiting Child for two or three months during the
  seventeen months between Child's removal and the TPR hearing.Â  According to
  Kathleen Spell, the DSS case manager, Mother and Father took snacks, drinks,
  toys, lotion for Child's skin issue, and antibiotics to Child.Â  Mother also testified
  they provided toys, food, clothes, diapers, wipes, medication, and lotion.Â  In
  anticipation of Child returning home, Mother redecorated the smaller bedroom
  for Child by painting, installing curtains and carpet, and rearranging
  furniture.Â  
Spell
  testified she attempted to evaluate improvements to the home on several
  occasions, but Mother and Father prevented her from entering.Â  The last time
  she visited, they permitted her to enter the house, but she left before
  completing her evaluation because Father cursed at her, yelled, and slammed
  doors.Â  
Wendy
  May of South Carolina Vocational Rehabilitation (SCVR) testified she saw Mother
  on June 12, 2007.Â  May offered Mother guidance counseling, GED preparation
  classes, and job readiness training.Â  SCVR offered Mother van transportation to
  its GED classes and job readiness training sessions, but she declined.Â  Mother
  attended a few classes but did not complete any of the programs within the
  first year.Â  On the date of the TPR hearing, Mother had been re-enrolled for
  approximately one month.Â  
Maria
  Royle, Child's guardian ad litem (GAL), testified Child appeared reluctant to
  spend time with Mother and Father, and they had to "bribe" her with
  treats.Â  According to Royle, Child bonded with her foster family and called her
  foster mother "Mommy."Â  Royle believed it was in Child's best
  interest to terminate Mother's and Father's parental rights so Child and her
  siblings could be adopted by their foster family.Â  She expressed concern that
  despite being "in the system" since 1991, Mother and Father had
  failed to rehabilitate themselves from their history of drug use and arrests.Â  
The
  family court terminated Mother's and Father's parental rights pursuant to sections 20-7-1572 (3) and (4) of the
  South Carolina Code (2007) (willful failure to visit and willful failure to
  support, respectively).Â  The family court
  also found TPR was in Child's best interests.Â  Mother now appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Â "A
  ground for [TPR] must be proved by clear and convincing evidence."Â  Richland
    County Dep't of Soc. Servs. v. Earles, 330 S.C. 24, 32, 496 S.E.2d 864, 868
  (1998).Â  "In reviewing a termination of parental rights, the appellate
  court has the authority to review the record and make its own findings of
  whether clear and convincing evidence supports the termination."Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Willful
  Failure to Visit
Mother
  argues the family court erred in finding DSS proved by clear and convincing
  evidence she willfully failed to visit Child.Â  We agree.Â  
One
  ground for TPR is proven when:

  The
    child has lived outside the home of either parent for a period of six months,
    and during that time the parent has wilfully failed to visit the child.Â  The
    court may attach little or no weight to incidental visitations, but it must be
    shown that the parent was not prevented from visiting by the party having
    custody or by court order.Â  The distance of the child's placement from the
    parent's home must be taken into consideration when determining the ability to
    visit. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 63-7-2570(3)
  (2010).Â  "Willful conduct is conduct that evinces a settled purpose to
  forego parental duties . . . because it manifests a conscious indifference to
  the rights of the child to receive support and consortium from the parent."Â  Charleston County Dep't of Soc. Servs. v. Jackson, 368 S.C. 87, 97, 627
  S.E.2d 765, 771 (Ct. App. 2006) (internal quotation marks omitted).Â  Whether
  the failure to visit is willful "is a question of intent to be determined
  from the facts and circumstances of each individual case."Â  S.C. Dep't
    of Soc. Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 610, 582 S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003).Â  
South
  Carolina courts have not quantified how many visits a parent may make while
  legally failing to visit.Â  Rather, the family court and this court are required
  to examine "the facts and circumstances" of this particular case to
  determine whether Mother's failure was willful.Â  See id.Â  In the
  instant case, the record is more deficient than informative.Â  It reflects that,
  during the approximately fifteen months Mother was permitted to visit Child,
  she made fourteen visits.Â  The visits were described as "sporadic,"
  and the GAL testified three of them occurred during the month preceding the TPR
  hearing.Â  However, no evidence indicated how many visits were scheduled, how
  many scheduled visits Mother missed, or how much time elapsed between visits.Â 
  According to the GAL, during the last month, Mother's visitation required the
  GAL to be present, but the record contained no evidence as to whether
  additional limitations or requirements applied to her other visits.Â  The GAL
  testified she had observed only Mother's last three visits with Child.Â 
  Although the GAL believed Mother and Child did not bond, no evidence indicated
  how long the visits lasted or what activities, if any, took place besides the
  presentation of toys and snacks.Â  The GAL testified that she personally visited
  Child approximately two times per month, but no evidence indicated whether
  Mother was invited to these visits.Â  Furthermore, the record contained no evidence
  of the distance between Mother's home and either the foster home or the
  visitation location.Â  Because Mother visited Child nearly once per month on
  average, and because the record fails to provide details of the purported
  failure to visit or clear indications of willfulness, the family court erred in
  finding DSS proved by clear and convincing evidence Mother willfully failed to
  visit Child.Â  
II. Willful
  Failure to Support
Mother
  asserts the family court erred in finding she willfully failed to support
  Child.Â  We agree.Â  
Another
  ground for TPR is met when:Â  

  The
    child has lived outside the home of either parent for a period of six months,
    and during that time the parent has wilfully failed to support the child.Â 
    Failure to support means that the parent has failed to make a material
    contribution to the child's care.Â  A material contribution consists of either
    financial contributions according to the parent's means or contributions of
    food, clothing, shelter, or other necessities for the care of the child
    according to the parent's means.Â  The court may consider all relevant
    circumstances in determining whether or not the parent has wilfully failed to
    support the child, including requests for support by the custodian and the
    ability of the parent to provide support. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 63-7-2570(4)
  (2010).Â  "Willful conduct is conduct that evinces a settled purpose to
  forego parental duties . . . because it manifests a conscious indifference to
  the rights of the child to receive support and consortium from the parent."Â  Jackson, 368 S.C. at 97, 627 S.E.2d at 771.Â  Whether the failure to
  support is willful "is a question of intent to be determined in each case
  from all the facts and circumstances."Â  S.C. Dep't of Soc. Servs. v.
    Seegars, 367 S.C. 623, 630, 627 S.E.2d 718, 721 (2006).Â  
The
  record clearly reflects that Mother had no income of her own.Â  The statute
  requires a "material contribution" of either money or necessities "according
  to the parent's means."Â  Â§ 63-7-2570(4).Â  The evidence adduced at the TPR
  hearing indicates Mother's means were extremely limited but she provided some
  necessities during her visits with Child.Â  Because of her inability to find
  employment, Mother either had no means whatsoever or was entirely dependent
  upon Father for means to support Child.Â  The family's only regular income came
  from Father's Social Security disability benefits.Â  Although Child received
  some amount of money from that source, the record does not indicate how much
  money Child received or when she began receiving it.Â  The payments appear to
  have started at the urging of the GAL, but aside from the entry of an order of
  support against Mother, no evidence indicates the GAL made additional requests
  for money from Mother.Â  More importantly, the record contains no evidence the
  family court examined the relevant circumstances to determine what would have
  constituted a material contribution according to Mother's means.Â  
We
  find unpersuasive Mother's argument that she was a housewife by choice.Â  Mother
  applied to dozens of jobs and diligently followed up on her applications until
  she received responses.Â  The record reflects she sought but failed to take full
  advantage of vocational rehabilitation services from SCVR, but the SCVR
  representative testified that SCVR was not a job placement agency.Â  Although
  SCVR offered services to assist individuals in becoming more marketable, it did
  not provide employment.Â  Consequently, even Mother's full, successful
  completion of SCVR's programs would not have guaranteed her income.Â  
Mother
  contends that, lack of income notwithstanding, she made material contributions
  to Child.Â  Child's DSS case manager testified Mother and Father provided child
  with snacks, drinks, toys, lotion for Child's skin issue, and antibiotics.Â 
  Mother testified they provided toys, food, clothes, diapers, wipes, medication,
  and lotion.Â  Lastly, Mother testified that she had prepared the smaller bedroom
  in their home for Child by painting, installing curtains and carpet, and
  rearranging furniture.Â  Considering her extremely limited means, Mother's
  efforts do not appear to "evince[] a settled purpose to forego parental
  duties."Â  See Jackson, 368 S.C. at 97, 627 S.E.2d at 771.Â 
  Therefore, the family court erred in finding DSS proved by clear and convincing
  evidence that Mother willfully failed to support Child.Â  
III. Best Interests
Finally,
  Mother asserts the family court erred in conducting a best-interests analysis
  despite DSS's failure to prove any statutory ground by clear and convincing
  evidence.Â  Because we reverse the family court's grant of TPR on the statutory
  grounds, we do not reach this issue.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing
    of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling
  an appellate court need not review remaining issues when its determination of a prior issue
  is dispositive of the appeal). 

CONCLUSION
In
  accordance with the foregoing, we reverse the family court's termination of
  Mother's parental rights and remand for a permanency planning hearing.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 63-7-2580(B) (2010) ("If the court finds that no ground
  for termination exists and the child is in the custody of [DSS], the order
  denying termination must specify a new permanent plan for the child or order a
  hearing on a new permanent plan.").
REVERSED AND REMANDED.Â  
CURETON, A.J., concurs.Â  
WILLIAMS, J., dissenting:Â  Â Â I respectfully dissent and
  would affirm the grant of TPR in this case, finding the family court correctly
  found clear and convincing evidence that Mother willfully failed to support
  Child.  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 63-7-2570(4)
  (2010) (stating a ground for TPR exists when "[t]he child has lived
  outside the home of either parent for a period of six months, and during that
  time the parent has wilfully failed to support the child" either
  financially or through material contributions to the child's care); see also Richland County Dep't of Soc.
    Servs. v. Earles, 330 S.C. 24, 32, 496 S.E.2d 864, 868 (1998) ("A
  ground for [TPR] must be proved by clear and convincing evidence.").  Our courts have held that "[c]onduct of the
  parent which evinces a settled purpose to forego parental duties may fairly be
  characterized as 'willful' because it manifests a conscious indifference to the
  rights of the child to receive support and consortium from the parent."Â  Hooper
    v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 297, 513 S.E.2d 358, 367 (1999).Â  
I would find there is sufficient evidence in this record to
  support the finding that Mother's failure to support Child was willful.Â  Mother admits that she paid no child
  support, despite her proven ability to earn an income based on her testimony
  that prior to April 2004 she held three jobs simultaneously.  In her
  brief, Mother argues she intentionally remained at home by agreement with her
  husband, choosing to remain dependent upon Father's Social Security disability
  income for all her needs rather than returning to work to help support this
  child or any of her other six children.  Her position is that is it is
  unfair to consider that she prefers to remain in the home as a housewife
  instead of working to support Child.Â  No evidence indicates Mother's presence
  was required at home to care for Father.  In fact, Father testified that
  despite his disability, he performed lawn care and odd jobs for additional
  money.  With all seven children removed from the home, Mother was free to
  seek gainful employment.  However, evidence that she pursued employment is
  scant and contradictory.Â  She testified that she submitted thirty job applications,
  but on cross-examination she admitted this was different than the testimony
  given one month earlier in another TPR action involving one of her other
  children.Â  Mother does not argue on appeal that she is disabled and unable to
  work.Â  In fact, Mother testified that during the month prior to the merits
  hearing, she redecorated Child's room by repainting, installing carpet, and
  moving furniture.Â  She testified she did take a day off from redecorating
  because her back hurt.Â  However, she indicated she was still able to use that
  time to grocery shop and to submit job applications.Â  
Evidence is plentiful that she eschewed not only employment but
  also any professional assistance that would have improved her ability to find
  work.  Although Mother initially sought assistance from SCVR, she failed
  for over fifteen months to take advantage of any of the several programs they
  offered that could have improved her workplace skills and her
  employability.  Not surprisingly, she even refused offers of
  transportation to get her to these classes.Â  She attended so infrequently that
  she was dropped from their rolls.  Accordingly, it is clear the inability
  of Mother to find employment was because Mother had neither the desire nor the
  intention to provide financial support for Child.Â  Most importantly, Mother
  testified that she and Father agreed she would not work outside the home even
  though she had a responsibility to support Child.
Finally, I believe any contributions Mother made to Child's
  welfare were not material.  Testimony indicated Mother provided a few
  items for Child during her initial visits.  The GAL testified that Mother
  provided nothing during her last three visits, which occurred during the month
  immediately preceding the TPR hearing.  Consequently, Mother's efforts to
  provide for Child were negligible. 
Moreover, the record demonstrates the best interest of Child would
  be served by granting TPR.Â Â  
Accordingly, I would find there is clear and convincing evidence
  of her failure to support Child.Â  Mother's choices indicate a clear and settled
  purpose to forego her parental responsibilities to support Child.Â  Therefore, I
  would affirm the family court's decision to terminate Mother's parental rights.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS)
  first became involved with Mother and Father in 1991.Â  Mother and Father had
  seven children.Â  In April 2004, before Child's birth, DSS removed the other
  children from Mother and Father's home. Â Mother's and Father's parental rights
  to the other six children were terminated October 7, 2008, in a separate action.
[3] The record does not make clear what improvements to
  the home the family court ordered or why.Â  One month before Child's removal,
  the home was inspected and found to be safe.Â  The sole reason for Child's
  removal was her parents' positive cocaine tests, which occurred on May 16,
  2007.Â  However, Mother tested negative for drugs on May 3, 2007; May 29, 2007;
  November 1, 2007; April 21, 2008; and September 27, 2008.Â Â Â  
[4] However, Dr. Lois Masouris testified she provided
  Mother and Father with three sessions of "Triple P" parenting
  training but could not complete the course without Child's attendance.Â  Dr.
  Masouris wrote to DSS requesting Child's attendance at ten future sessions, but
  DSS never responded. Â 
[5] Mother and Father do not have a landline telephone.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        James Moore, Respondent,
        v.
        Jeannette M. Benson and Thomas Lee Benson, Jr., Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Gordon G. Cooper, Master-in-Equity

Opinion No.Â Â  4745
  Submitted May 3, 2010 â€“ Filed September
22, 2010

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND
  REMANDED


  
    
      
        Jessica Ann Salvini, of Greenville, for Appellants.
        Edwin C. Haskell, III, and Chadwick Dean Pye, both of Spartanburg,
          for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: James
  Moore filed this action against Jeannette M. Benson and Thomas Lee Benson
  seeking damages and equitable relief based on allegations of inter alia,
  fraud, conversion, and breach of fiduciary duty arising from the sale of real
  property from Moore to the Bensons. Â The master ordered the Bensons to reconvey
  the property to Moore, and awarded Moore actual and punitive damages. Â This
  appeal followed. Â We affirm in part,
  reverse in part, and remand.[1]
FACTS
Moore was eighty-eight years old at the time of the trial in 2008.
  Moore and Allean Moore were married in 1949. Â Throughout the marriage, Allean
  handled the bills and personal business. Â Moore and Allean lived on seventeen
  acres in Lyman, South Carolina, in the marital home. 
Moore's daughter, Jeannette, testified she began the caretaking of
  her father as early as 1989. Â According to Jeannette, BB&T sent Moore a
  letter, dated January 14, 1999, stating that because Moore was to turn eighty,
  his retirement account needed to be closed and the money transferred to another
  account. Â The funds, $29,433.46, were transferred into account #471,
  Jeannette's account. Jeannette testified Moore stated: "Jeannette, you
  have been taking care [of] me all of these years . . . . I am giving you all of
  this money." According to her, she was to continue to take care of Moore
  and pay his bills. Â On February 16, 1999, Moore signed a durable power of
  attorney, appointing Jeannette as his attorney-in-fact.
Moore and Allean were divorced by family court orders filed on
  November 3, 2000, and January 8, 2001. Â The divorce decree awarded Moore the
  marital home, valued by the family court at $154,000, and further provided:

  9. Husband is to inform wife, within forty-five (45) days of the
    date of this Order, relative to his election to buy her out; if he is able, or
    elects to do so, this is to be done within ninety (90) days of the date of this
    Order. 
  10. If husband is unable or unwilling to buy out wife's interest,
    then within forty-five (45) days of the date of this Order, the home is to be
    placed on the market for sale, under the control of the husband; upon the sale
    of the home, wife's interest in the marital estate is to be paid forthwith; if
    the home is not under contract for sale within six (6) months of being placed
    on the market, wife has the election to petition the Court for a judicial
    sale.Â  

In the order addressing Allean's motion to reconsider, the family
  court ordered Moore to pay $52,851 to Allean to effectuate the order relative
  to equitable distribution. 
On March 8, 2001, account #471, with a balance of $30,338.35 was
  closed, withdrawing $30,215.82 and incurring a $122.53 early withdrawal penalty.
  Â The withdrawal check was made payable to Jeannette. On March 9, 2001, Moore
  signed a purchase contract and HUD settlement statement, selling the marital
  home to the Bensons.[2]Â 
  The price paid for the property, $56,294.41, was the amount necessary to pay costs,
  a small mortgage remaining on the property, and the equitable distribution
  amount due to Allean.Â Â  
John H. Heckman, III, a real estate attorney, testified he knew
  many of the Moore family members, including Moore, from a previous family land
  dispute. Â Heckman testified Jeannette and her husband Thomas were purchasing
  Moore's house to enable Moore to pay Allean her equitable distribution award. Â Heckman
  stated he met with Jeannette and Moore in his conference room and explained
  each document to Moore. Moore appeared to understand he was selling his
  property. Â The proceeds check from the sale was made payable to Allean's
  attorney. 
Moore testified he has a fifth-grade education and cannot read. Â He
  also testified Jeannette took over paying his bills after his divorce. Â He
  stated Jeannette would have him sign papers from time to time, but she did not
  explain to him what he was signing. Â He denied gifting the funds from his
  retirement account to Jeannette. Â He claimed he did not know he had signed a
  power of attorney or closing documents to sell his property. Â Moore testified
  he did not intend to sell the property to the Bensons, and he did not talk to
  Heckman at the closing. Â He testified he was in the hall at Heckman's office
  and Jeannette brought papers out for him to sign.
Jeannette testified Moore could read, stating he read the
  newspaper, his driver's manual, and readings in church.Â  She testified she used
  the money withdrawn from Moore's retirement account to pay his expenses, such
  as his divorce attorney's fees of approximately $15,000, and medical bills. Â She
  testified Moore asked her to obtain money to pay the equitable distribution
  award from her siblings. Â She testified she could not get any of them to
  provide financial help. 
Jeannette took Moore to Heckman's office. Â According to her,
  Heckman explained "everything" to Moore and he understood. Â She
  agreed to pay all of the taxes and insurance on the house, and Moore could live
  there for the remainder of his life. 
Thomas, Jeannette's husband, testified he cashed in a $20,000
  certificate of deposit, a savings bond worth more than $5,000, and borrowed
  $20,000 to contribute to the purchase of the house. Â He stated Moore
  contributed the remaining $10,000 from the funds transferred to Jeannette's
  name. Â Thomas also testified he was at the closing, and Moore was present and
  "fine." 
The master found Jeannette breached her fiduciary duty to Moore
  and converted Moore's retirement account. Â He further found the Bensons paid
  for the property partially with funds belonging to Moore. Â He also found the
  Bensons intentionally concealed the truth from Moore and "were not only
  dishonest but in light of the facts of this case outrageous . . . ." Â The
  master ordered the Bensons to reconvey the property to Moore, pay actual
  damages of $3,770.26, and pay punitive damages of $25,000. Â This appeal
  followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
"When legal and equitable actions are maintained in one suit, each retains its
  own identity as legal or equitable for purposes of the applicable standard of review on appeal." Â Corley v. Ott, 326 S.C. 89, 92 n.1, 485 S.E.2d 97, 99 n.1 (1997). Â The reviewing court should "view the actions separately for the purpose of determining the
  appropriate standard of review." Â Jordan v. Holt, 362 S.C. 201, 205, 608
  S.E.2d 129, 131 (2005). Â In an action in equity, tried by the judge alone, without a reference,
  the appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its own view
  of the preponderance of the evidence. Â Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of
    Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976). Â On the other
  hand, when reviewing an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a
  jury, the appellate court's jurisdiction is limited to the correction of errors
  at law, and the appellate court will not disturb the judge's findings of fact
  as long as they are reasonably supported by the evidence. Â Epworth
    Children's Home v. Beasley, 365 S.C. 157, 164, 616 S.E.2d 710, 714 (2005).
LAW/ANALYSIS
  

I. Statute of Limitations
The
  Bensons argue the master erred in denying their motion to dismiss based on the
  statute of limitations. Â We disagree.
This
  action is governed by a three-year statute of limitations period. S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 15-3-530 (2005); see Mazloom v. Mazloom, 382 S.C. 307,
  323, 675 S.E.2d 746, 755 (Ct. App. 2009) (citing three-year statute of
  limitations in breach of fiduciary duty action); Turner v. Milliman, 381
  S.C. 101, 109-10, 671 S.E.2d 636, 640 (Ct. App. 2009) (applying three-year
  statute of limitations in fraud action). 
The
  discovery rule applies to this action. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-535 (2005)
  (applying the discovery rule to causes of action arising under section
  15-3-530(5)); Rumpf v. Massachusetts Mut. Life Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 386, 394, 593 S.E.2d 183, 187 (Ct. App. 2004)
  (stating "[i]n determining when a
  cause of action arose under
  section 15-3-530, we apply the 'discovery rule'"). Â According
  to the discovery rule, the statute of limitations begins to run when a person
  could or should have known, through the exercise of reasonable diligence that a
  cause of action might exist. Â Abba Equip., Inc. v. Thomason, 335 S.C.
  477, 485, 517 S.E.2d 235, 239 (Ct. App. 1999). Â The date on which discovery of the cause of action should have been
  made is an objective question. Â Joubert v. S.C. Dep't of Soc. Servs.,
  341 S.C. 176, 191, 534 S.E.2d 1, 9 (Ct. App. 2000). Â In Young v. South
    Carolina Department of Corrections, this court stated:

  In other words, whether the particular plaintiff actually knew he
    had a claim is not the test. Rather, courts must decide whether the
    circumstances of the case would put a person of common knowledge and experience
    on notice that some right of his has been invaded, or that some claim against
    another party might exist.

333 S.C. 714,
  719, 511 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 1999).
The property transfer in this case was made on March 9, 2001. Â The
  action was not filed until October 2006. Â Moore testified he first became aware
  that something was amiss on December 25, 2005. When he was riding with the
  Bensons to Christmas dinner at his son Robert's house, Thomas asked who had
  permitted someone to park a truck on the subject property. Â Moore testified he had
  concern about why Thomas was asking about his property. 
Moore's son, James Luther Moore, Jr., testified Moore rode home
  with him from the Christmas dinner and Moore stated he heard Jeannette tell
  Thomas to "be quiet" when Thomas asked about the vehicle parked on
  the property. Â Moore allegedly explained to James that Thomas and Jeannette
  acted like the property belonged to them. Â According to James, Moore was also
  concerned that Thomas was picking up bottles and cans on the property and Moore
  wanted James's son, Marcus, to check on it. 
Marcus testified Moore and his father asked him to look into
  Moore's affairs a week or so after Christmas 2005. Â He found the property was
  titled to the Bensons. Â He later took Moore to the bank and received the bank
  records from 2000 to at least 2005. Â He explained the withdrawal of retirement funds
  to Moore, who denied withdrawing any money. Â Marcus also took Moore to
  Heckman's office to get copies of the closing documents on the property.
In this case, we look to when a person of common knowledge and
  experience under the circumstances of the case would have known that he sold
  his property to the Bensons. Â In light of the evidence that Jeannette handled
  Moore's personal affairs, we affirm the master's finding that the statute of
  limitations did not begin to run until Moore first had suspicions that
  something was amiss in December 2005.
II. Conversion
The
  Bensons argue the master erred in finding Jeannette converted Moore's
  retirement funds. Â We disagree.
"'Conversion'
  is defined as the unauthorized
  assumption and exercise of the rights of ownership over goods or personal
  chattels belonging to another, to the alteration of their condition or to the
  exclusion of the rights of the owner." Â Mullis v. Trident Emergency
    Physicians, 351 S.C. 503, 506-07, 570 S.E.2d 549, 550-51 (Ct. App. 2002).
  Â An action for conversion is an action at law. Â Blackwell v. Blackwell,
  289 S.C. 470, 471, 346 S.E.2d 731, 732 (Ct. App. 1986). Â Therefore, we
  review the record to determine if any evidence supports the master's finding. Â See id. (finding in an action for conversion where the appeal is based on
  alleged errors of fact, this court must affirm if there is any evidence reasonably
  supporting the findings of the trial court).
Moore presented evidence his retirement account was closed in
  January 1999, and the retirement funds were deposited into Jeannette's account.
  Â Moore testified he did not give the
  retirement funds to Jeannette. Â During direct examination, Moore was asked:
  "Did you give that money to anybody? Did you make a gift of that
  retirement money to anybody?" Â Moore responded: "No." Â We find evidence
  to support the master's finding of conversion.
III. Breach of Fiduciary Duty
The
  Bensons next argue the master erred in finding Jeannette breached her fiduciary
  duty to Moore. Â We disagree.
Our
  supreme court recently held that an action alleging a breach of fiduciary duty
  is an action at law but "may sound in equity if the relief sought is
  equitable." Â Verenes v. Alvanos, 387 S.C. 11, 17, 690 S.E.2d 771,
  773 (2010). Â The "[c]haracterization
  of an action as equitable or legal depends on the appellant's 'main purpose' in
  bringing the action.'" Â Id. at 16, 690 S.E.2d at 773 (quoting Ins.
    Fin. Servs., Inc. v. S.C. Ins. Co., 271 S.C. 289, 293, 247 S.E.2d 315, 318
  (1978)). Â We find the main purpose of the breach of fiduciary duty action in
  this case was for the equitable remedy to rescind the contract and reconvey the
  property to Moore. Â See Dixon v. Dixon, 362 S.C. 388, 395, 608
  S.E.2d 849, 852 (2005) (finding action to rescind contract and set aside deed
  is in equity). Â Thus, we may find facts in accordance with our own view of the
  preponderance of the evidence. Â See Felts v. Richland County, 303
  S.C. 354, 356, 400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991) (stating appellate court may find
  facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence in
  equitable actions).
"A
  fiduciary relationship exists when one reposes special confidence in another,
  so that the latter, in equity and good conscience, is bound to act in good
  faith and with due regard to the interests of the one reposing
  confidence." Â O'Shea v. Lesser, 308 S.C. 10, 15, 416 S.E.2d 629,
  631 (1992). Â "One standing in a fiduciary relationship with another is
  subject to liability to the other for harm resulting from a breach of duty
  imposed by the relation." Â Moore v. Moore, 360 S.C. 241, 253, 599
  S.E.2d 467, 473 (Ct. App. 2004); see In re Estate of Cumbee, 333
  S.C. 664, 672, 511 S.E.2d 390, 394 (Ct. App. 1999) (finding fiduciary
  relationship existed where a son had his mother's power of attorney and managed
  her finances).
Like
  the master, we find the timing of the withdrawal to Jeannette on March 8, 2001,
  of all funds in account #471, indicated the funds originally belonging to Moore
  were used by the Bensons as part of the purchase price of the property. Â The
  master further found Jeannette: 

  concocted
    a scheme whereby the [Bensons] could purchase property of James Moore for
    $56,294.41, which is approximately 37% of the value of the subject property . .
    . . In addition, the purchase price paid was funded partially from the funds
    that belonged to [Moore]. The [Bensons] through their intentional actions and
    representations made to [Moore] concealed the truth of the transaction from
    [Moore]. 

The
  master found Jeannette breached her fiduciary duty to Moore. Â After our own
  review of the record, we likewise find Jeannette breached her fiduciary duty
  owed to Moore and affirm the master's order directing the Bensons to reconvey
  the property to Moore.
IV. Property Taxes and
  Insurance
The
  Bensons argue the master erred in awarding damages by failing to credit them for property taxes and
  insurance payments they allegedly made. Â We find no error. 
Although
  Moore did not dispute the allegations and testimony that the Bensons paid these
  items, the Bensons provided no documentary evidence in support of their claims.
  Â The master, as the fact finder, was free to accept or reject the testimony. Â See S.C. Dep't of Transp. v. M&T Enters. of Mt. Pleasant, LLC, 379 S.C.
  645, 668 n.12, 667 S.E.2d 7, 20 n.12 (Ct. App. 2008) (finding the master in
  equity, as the trier of fact, is free to accept or reject all of a witness's
  testimony). Â We find no error by the master.
V. Award of Damages to Moore
The Bensons argue the master
  erred in finding Moore was entitled to damages because the master failed to
  consider the equitable distribution award and the outstanding mortgage on the
  property, paid on Moore's behalf from the proceeds of the sale.Â  We agree.
The Settlement Statement showed
  that from the proceeds of the sale of the property, Allean Moore was paid
  $52,851 and a mortgage on the property of $3,024.36 was paid in full, totaling
  $55,875.36.Â  The master found Moore was entitled to damages of $3,770.26 by
  subtracting the Bensons' contribution to the sales proceeds, $26,568.09, from
  the amount in account #471 at the time of the closing, $30,338.35. Â However,
  this fails to take into account Moore's debts of $55,875.36, which were paid
  off at the closing. Â From this, we find Moore is entitled to a credit for his
  retirement funds of $30,338.35, but must repay the Bensons for their
  contribution to the payment of his debts of $25,537.01.[3]
VI. Punitive Damages
The
  Bensons argue the master erred in awarding punitive damages because there were
  no actual damages. Â We agree. 
Punitive damages may only be awarded upon an underlying finding of actual damages. Â Keane v. Lowcounty Pediatrics, 372 S.C.
  136, 148, 641 S.E.2d 53, 60 (Ct. App. 2007). Â In Keane, this court
  reversed the actual damages award, on which an award of punitive damages was
  based. Â Id. at 149, 641 S.E.2d at 60. Â Thus, this court likewise
  reversed the punitive damages stating "without a finding of actual damages
  . . . the award of punitive damages is reversed." Â Id.
In
  this case, the master's award of actual damages failed to take into account
  debts paid on Moore's behalf. Â As the final calculation of damages requires
  Moore to reimburse the Bensons in the amount of $25,537.01, we find no actual
  damages due to Moore, and reverse the award of punitive damages pursuant to Keane.
CONCLUSION
For
  the foregoing reasons, we affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand for entry
  of judgment in accordance with this opinion.
AFFIRMED
  IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
SHORT,
  HUFF, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The Purchase Contract is dated March 1, 2001.Â  The
  HUD Settlement Statement and the Title to Real Estate are dated March 9, 2001.Â  
[3] Moore argues this issue is not preserved for
  appellate review.Â  The HUD-1 Settlement Statement, which included information
  regarding the equitable distribution award and outstanding mortgage, was
  introduced into evidence and considered by the master.Â  The master also ordered
  a credit against Moore's award.Â  We find this issue was before the court and
  preserved for our review.Â  See Spence v. Wingate, 381 S.C. 487,
  489-90, 674 S.E.2d 169, 169 (2009) (finding an issue preserved despite the
  failure to file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion where the issue was raised to and
  ruled upon by the trial court).
